content: The "Boutique Fuels Reduction Act of 2004" allows for temporary waivers during supply emergencies. The Clean Air Act allows the Administrator to temporarily waive fuel or fuel additive regulations in cases of extreme supply circumstances, such as natural disasters or equipment failures. The Clean Air Act permits the Administrator to grant a temporary waiver for fuel or fuel additive regulations in cases of unforeseen events like natural disasters or equipment failures. The waiver must be in the public interest and only apply to the smallest necessary area for a maximum of 20 days, or a shorter period if deemed sufficient. The Administrator can grant a temporary waiver for fuel regulations in cases of extreme circumstances, allowing a transitional period for wholesalers and retailers to adjust their inventory. The waiver applies to all persons in the motor fuel distribution system, with public notice required. The term 'motor fuel distribution system' will be defined by the Administrator through rulemaking within 180 days of the enactment of the Boutique Fuels Reduction Act of 2004. The Administrator will define the term 'motor fuel distribution system' through rulemaking within 180 days of the Boutique Fuels Reduction Act of 2004. Regulations to implement certain clauses must be promulgated within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act does not limit other waiver authorities or subject States or individuals to enforcement actions solely based on waiver issuance. SEC. 3. CAP ON NUMBER OF BOUTIQUE FUELS. Section 211(c)(4)(C) of the Clean Air Act is amended to restrict the approval of new fuels in State implementation plans, limiting the total number of approved fuels and requiring existing fuels to be replaced in certain circumstances. The Clean Air Act restricts the approval of new fuels in State implementation plans, limiting the total number of approved fuels and allowing existing fuels to be replaced without increasing the total number of fuels approved. States can still require the use of registered fuel additives. SEC. 4. STUDY AND REPORT TO CONGRESS ON BOUTIQUE FUELS. The Administrator of the EPA and the Secretary of Energy will conduct a study on the impact of State plan provisions on air quality, fuel availability, and costs. The focus is on developing a Federal fuels system to maximize fuel supply, preserve air quality, and reduce price volatility. Coordination with affected parties will be done to gather comments on air quality impacts. The Administrator and the Secretary will coordinate with affected parties to gather comments on the air quality impact assessment and fuel-related aspects of the study. A joint report to Congress with recommendations for regulatory and legislative changes is due within 12 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy.
